Legal_Issue: Whether Saks & Co. sufficiently demonstrated use of the 'Saks Fifth Avenue' trademark in Canada
Procedural_Stage: Appeal to Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division
Evidence_Assessment: Sales slips and statements showing deliveries to Canadian addresses for 14 categories of goods were reviewed; sufficient for some categories, insufficient for others
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed in part: registration maintained for 14 categories, expungement upheld for the rest
Burden_of_Proof: On trademark owner (Saks & Co.) to demonstrate use in Canada under Section 44
Legal_Rule: Section 44 of the Trade Marks Act requires evidence of use in Canada or special circumstances excusing non-use
Procedural_Issue: Additional evidence considered on appeal beyond Registrar's review
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of use of trademark in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for appellant; partial maintenance of registration
Decision_Maker: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales slips, sales statements, delivery records to Canadian addresses
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, specifically Trade Marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Saks & Co. challenged expungement initiated by Registrar
Court_Result: Registration maintained for 14 categories, expunged for others; no costs awarded
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 44 of the Trade Marks Act
Standard_of_Proof: Preponderance of evidence / balance of probabilities
Defendant_Response: Registrar initiated expungement due to alleged non-use
Remedy_Sought: Maintain registration of 'Saks Fifth Avenue' trademark for all goods categories
Legal_Provision: Section 44 of the Trade Marks Act
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Federal Court of Canada
Governing_Rule: Section 44 of the Trade Marks Act
